FOREWORD  
We have officially entered the Age of Artificial Intelligence. The world is now set to change at a pace not seen in decades, even 
centuries. AI-based tools and applications make our lives easier, smoother, and richer. They help us move efficiently, get informed, 
get credit, get a job, and get our taxes done.
 
But in its current form, AI reproduces and amplifies many of the social challenges we face. It is not acceptable that around a third 
of the world’s population still lacks adequate internet access. Upstream, the AI industry is highly concentrated, with just two 
countries – the United States and China – and a dozen companies accounting for a major share of the sector. This can lead only 
to greater inequality of outcomes – including gender disparities – downstream. Non-diverse AI teams, unrepresentative datasets, 
and opaque and biased algorithms can cause harm, particularly to those who are already vulnerable, whether companies or 
individuals, children and young people, women, or entire democracies.
 
That is why UNESCO drafted the Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which was adopted in 2021 by 193 
countries to make sure AI delivers fair, sustainable, and inclusive outcomes. The Recommendation is based on the protection and 
promotion of human rights, human dignity, and environmental sustainability, and these values are then translated into principles

recommendations.text: The Ministry of Youth Empowerment, Sports and Recreation should prime itself for the increasingly relevant role that AI plays in the sports sector. Although this is generally ignored in current AI development discussions, key areas of AI relevance in Sports include sports science (e.g using computer vision to analyse player movement and enhance injury prevention actions), enhancing athletes performance through big data analytics of gaming strategies and performance trends, doping detection, sport equipment design, E-sports and gaming, and the sports betting industry. A good starting point is innovation (whether in adoption or creation of local solutions) and the preparedness to tackle the risks it poses – not the least of which is contextual adaptability in a sector that is heavily designed for maximising social human interactions. 29 Action 2a: Discuss policies and/or regulations as part of an updated national AI strategy. Time frame for this is estimated to be 3 months with the process to be driven by MITCI. Action 2b: Review sector-based progress of the existing strategy and propose corrective measures based on recent learnings. Redefine priority sectors as needed based upon the evolution of the Mauritian economy and the updated socioeconomic contexts highlighted above. Time frame to achieve this review is estimated to be 6 months and to be driven by the METC. B. Ethical review processes are starting to be implemented in some international AI conferences such as Neural Information Processing Systems 202440. For Mauritius to benefit from these measures, it must provide its AI researchers with access to the relevant training and best practices to properly prepare their submissions, as well as financial support to attend such events.

recommendations.title: Review and enhance funding mechanisms.
recommendations.text: Review and enhance funding mechanisms. Current mechanisms for funding and incentivizing human capital development should be continually monitored and evaluated. Consider reassessing compensation structures for funding instruments that support advanced human capital development. This revision should facilitate international collaboration networks and prevent experts from returning without suitable academic or industry positions.

recommendations.title: The government must increase expenditure on research.
recommendations.text: The government must increase expenditure on research. The private sector should also be encouraged to contribute more to research activities to benefit from innovative solutions. To begin, the government must allocate resources for industry-university collaboration to support domain-specific AI development, prioritise sectors highlighted in the updated AI strategy. More initiatives such as the collaborative public-private sectors research grants need to be devised and funded. Enhanced incentives must be discussed with partners from academia with the proposed interministerial workgroup, with a view to increasing the amount and quality of AI research outputs.

recommendations.title: Evaluate the Digital Transformation Strategy in Education.
recommendations.text: Evaluate the Digital Transformation Strategy in Education. Monitor and assess outcomes of the current Digital Transformation Strategy in Education to gauge its effectiveness and relevance in building human capital for AI. Based on these evaluations and lessons learned, consider the establishment of specific laws or policies related to the use of AI in the education system. 33

recommendations.title: Promote the development and integration of PhD holders into the industry.
recommendations.text: Promote the development and integration of PhD holders into the industry. This can be done by commissioning the Higher Education Commission (HEC) to design, pilot and implement measures such as establishing collaborative PhD programs with industry partners, offering funding for research internships in the industry, and tax incentives for companies hiring PhD holders.

recommendations.title: Incorporate AI and ethics awareness into school curricula.
recommendations.text: Incorporate AI and ethics awareness into school curricula. Recent curriculum transformations incorporating elements of computational thinking, critical thinking, programming, AI, and ethics are still optional and therefore not offered to all students. This report recommends initiating a comprehensive review process that not only identifies the curriculum components requiring modification and incorporation but also develops a plan for updating and providing teacher training to accommodate these changes.

recommendations.title: Support teacher training in AI use
recommendations.text: Support teacher training in AI use: The Ministry of Education has already started these discussions, through the ‘AI in Education’ project. The Ministry should scale such initiatives by developing support guides for all teachers in the use of AI and related tools. This ongoing support will be crucial in enhancing educators’ capabilities to integrate AI and related subjects into the school curriculum.

recommendations.title: Collect and maintain data for human capital development in AI, in collaboration with higher education institutions.
recommendations.text: Collect and maintain data for human capital development in AI, in collaboration with higher education institutions. This data should encompass metrics like enrollment and graduation rates, with a particular focus on identifying and addressing gender disparities. These statistics can be gathered and shared for research purposes through existing educational institutions, such as the HEC. Action 8: Implement the proposals set out above to close the AI skills gap. To be led by the Ministry of Education, with the support of MITCI, METC and MDPA. Time frame is 2 years. 9. DATA: ADDRESS THE DATA GAP Most AI applications, specifically ML and deep learning algorithms, rely critically upon data to produce targeted results. Inadequate, poor quality, and biased data are well-known challenges in building ethical AI systems. This issue is global but is compounded by peculiar factors in Mauritius. For example, while a significant number of datasets are available as part of the open dataset repository managed by the MDPA, the breadth of data available, usually government-based data, could be viewed as limited for purposes of advanced analytics. Hence, there is a need to augment or supplement with data from other sources, but data merging between different dataset technologies is a recurrent challenge that can inhibit creation of beneficial datasets. Furthermore, many organisations either do not have enough data or have data that is not available in machine-readable formats. Although e-government initiatives have begun, many private and public institutions have historically relied on paper-based data. Thus, for applications requiring long series data, converting paper-based data to digital formats will require substantial efforts and resources. Action 9: Improve capability to capture and generate datasets whilst promoting data engineering and improving data scientists’ skill sets. findings: LEGAL AND REGULATORY AI POLICY AND REGULATION The 2018 AI strategy was driven by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development and was proposed by a working group.
The strategy focused on proposing projects based on priority areas, taking a vertical approach toward AI strategy and potentially subsequent recommendations that could result in policies.
The strategy mentions and discusses briefly the impact of ethical considerations for the use of AI.

Similarly, the potential impact of AI upon human rights is touched upon in the section mentioning challenges with implementation of AI focusing mostly upon loss of jobs, but there are no dedicated, detailed and comprehensive discussions focusing on other critical aspects such as how human rights mig
The working group submitted a proposed strategy and recommended that implementation aspects be addressed by the Mauritius AI Council (MAIC).
Thus, the METC is the public body responsible for implementing sensible proposals regarding AI strategies for Mauritius.

In addition, Mauritius needs to conduct ethical impact assessments of AI- based tools and reflect on the most effective way to enforce monitoring and evaluation of any policy or regulations as part of any comprehensive strategy, regulations and policies.

DATA PROTECTION AND PRIVACY LAWS The International Telecommunication Union (ITU)’s 2020 Global Cybersecurity Index4 gives Mauritius a score of 96.89%, which places it on the 17th position globally and 1st in Africa.
strengths: Mauritius has also adopted a National Cybersecurity Strategy 2023-26.

gaps: Although no formal and publicly available documented assessment of the strategy is yet available, there is a rethinking discussion to determine the relevance of the strategy to the current context of Mauritius, as elaborated in the preceding section.
One major challenge with the working group was that only one member could be said to have domain-specific expertise in terms of AI strategic thinking.
However, it contains no focused and dedicated section on policies and regulations that would promote ethical development and use of AI in Mauritius.

Mauritius has not yet implemented any binding AI regulations, soft law or policies, but at the level of the METC and Ministry of Information Technology, Communication and Innovation (MITCI), discussions have commenced about AI policies and even some regulations.

The results of the UNESCO Readiness Assessment Methodology (RAM) could prove to be a boon to the institution of policies or regulations, in that the RAM implies clearly that aspects of the Mauritius AI landscape such as budgetary concerns related to some AI strategy need to be addressed.

findings: To transition towards a more emerging tech economy, it is crucial to get a higher percentage of GDP focused on R&D in general with some significant portion focused on AI in the short term.
However, data from the OECD AI Policy Observatory15 shows that Mauritius’ leading institution, the University of Mauritius16, has produced about 629 AI-related publications from 2000 till 2023.

The Center for Security and Emerging Technology’s Country Activity Tracker17 on AI publications by country places Mauritius in the 16th position in Africa and 109th globally on AI publications This shows there is much to be improved on by providing more incentives for research and an easier patent p
Research and research enablers focused on ethical AI research are extremely minimal at this stage.
Regarding AI talent innovation output, though the number of AI researchers is unknown and therefore would warrant some official data capture, there are researchers whose main area of focus is AI.
This denotes that, compared to other countries, the amount of applied AI output is still very low.
The number of AI-based patents is also unknown but is estimated to be minimal.

EDUCATION With respect to education strategy connected with AI, the Mauritian government currently runs an Artificial Intelligence (AI) skills development support programme19 which aims to boost university students’ AI skills and to overall improve local capabilities in AI development.
strengths: For context, other leading Sub-Saharan Africa AI countries, such as South Africa and Nigeria have had their leading institutions, the University of Pretoria and the University of Nigeria, produce about 5,650 and 1,158 AI-related publications, respectively.
gaps: Data on research output focused on AI is limited.
While internet use might be more widespread (at 75.5%), a large proportion of this use is for social networking, suggesting that digital literacy remains quite limited in Mauritius.
Much still needs to be done with regards to integrating AI perspectives into education policies in Mauritius.

Although ICT and Engineering remain among the top 5 courses of choice for higher education enrolment in Mauritius, the percentage of students enrolling in science and technology-related courses generally has declined over the years, from 29.3 percent in 2015 to 25.1% in 202223.

However, these ideas will benefit from some review to re-adjust to the current context.

findings: From the operational perspective, the METC has been formed as one of the outcomes of the national AI strategy, and is expected to drive and collaborate on any type of emerging technology initiative.
From the technological perspective, the burst of LLMs has convinced the global society of the potential and importance of AI, whether in a substantiated or hyped way.

Amongst the main issues identified regarding AI regulations and policies for Mauritius are the following: • At the strategic level, a structure is needed that would act as an updated think tank examining the national AI strategy, as well as an operational structure for acting upon the recommendation

• Some of the expectations of AI could be unrealistic, so general awareness regarding what is possible with AI systems, particularly in light of cost and technology constraints, is needed.

The formulation of a policy taking into consideration AI-driven cloud computing delivery should be integrated within the overall upcoming AI national policies.
The performance in the sector of data management and governance is once more relatively good.
Many organisations have well invested in data management infrastructure, skill sets, compliance with regulations and quality of data processes.
There are no national data management policies, but such policies would not be expected as practices could be industry specific.
Hence, many organisations, such as those in the financial industry, adopt well known and respected data management guidelines issued by professional bodies in the industry.

achievements.achievement: Ethical review processes are starting to be implemented in some international AI conferences such as Neural Information Processing Systems 202440.

Ethics components in graduate student committee meetings or theses could be introduced, and ethics checklists can be implemented for use at the beginning of a student project, followed by periodic check-ins.

Mauritius has not yet implemented any binding AI regulations, soft law or policies, but at the level of the METC and Ministry of Information Technology, Communication and Innovation (MITCI), discussions have commenced about AI policies and even some regulations.
However, there is no specific policy for procurement of AI systems that would contain, for example, a list of recognized AI systems suppliers.
Even though a national data sharing framework was devised in 2016, the stakeholders did not have a clear understanding of how it has been implemented and whether it has been reviewed and updated.
Even though no digital health policy had been implemented at the time of the survey, it was a matter of high importance with one regulation for digital health being prepared and targeted for 2024.

On the legal and regulatory front, Mauritius has not yet implemented any binding AI regulations, soft law or policies, and while discussions have begun at the METC and the MITCI levels, current approaches focus too heavily on the economic prospects of AI, with very little discussions around ethics and broader societal inclusion.
